schema_place.name: Galehead Mountain
schema_place.description: Galehead Mountain is a 4,024 foot peak in New Hampshire offering hiking trails with scenic views.

mainEntity.name: How long does it take to hike Galehead Mountain?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most routes on Galehead Mountain take 5-7 hours round trip. The most popular trail is 10.2 miles with Hard difficulty. Start early, especially on weekends when parking fills quickly.

mainEntity.name: Is Galehead Mountain hard to hike?

acceptedAnswer.text: Galehead Mountain is rated Hard. At 4,024 feet, expect challenging terrain above treeline with potential for rapid weather changes. Proper footwear and preparation are essential.

mainEntity.name: Do I need a permit to hike Galehead Mountain?

acceptedAnswer.text: No hiking permit is required for Galehead Mountain. However, parking fees may apply at trailheads (typically $3-5/day for WMNF or state parks). A WMNF parking pass covers most White Mountain trailheads.

mainEntity.name: What is the best trail to hike Galehead Mountain?

acceptedAnswer.text: The most popular route is the Gale River Trail to Galehead, offering Route via Galehead Hut to wooded summit..

mainEntity.name: When is the best time to hike Galehead Mountain?

acceptedAnswer.text: The best hiking season for Galehead Mountain is late May through October. Summer and fall offer the best conditions, though expect crowds on weekends. Winter hiking requires specialized gear and experience.

page_content.description:
At 4,024 feet, Galehead Mountain ranks among New Hampshire's celebrated 4000-Footers‚Äîa collection of 48 peaks that challenge and inspire hikers throughout the Northeast. This hard summit offers a quintessential White Mountain experience.

Popular Routes

The most popular route, **Gale River Trail to Galehead**, covers 10.2 miles and is rated Hard. Route via Galehead Hut to wooded summit.

Peak Bagging

**Extend Your Adventure:** South Twin Mountain lies just 0.9 miles away, making it an excellent addition for ambitious hikers looking to bag multiple summits.

spring.title: Spring Conditions
spring.conditions: Muddy trails, snow above 3000ft until May
spring.tips: Trail closures for mud season (April-May). Check conditions before heading out.

summer.title: Summer Conditions
summer.tips: Start early to avoid afternoon storms and parking issues. Peak crowds on weekends.

fall.title: Fall Conditions
fall.conditions: Peak foliage late Sept, early snow possible in October
fall.tips: Peak foliage brings peak crowds. Weekday hikes recommended. Watch for ice above treeline in late October.

winter.title: Winter Conditions
winter.conditions: Full winter conditions, extreme cold and wind above treeline
winter.tips: Winter hiking requires specialized skills and gear. Never hike alone. Check avalanche conditions for steeper terrain.

current_hazards: ‚ö†Ô∏è ALPINE ZONE: Weather changes rapidly. Turn back if conditions deteriorate.
